semantic_identifier: 8771293 - Jetstream Vale Aviation - buy - Discussion with Teresa Flores

hierarchy.meeting_title: 8771293 - Jetstream Vale Aviation - buy - Discussion with Teresa Flores

sections.text: Megan Foster: Hi Teresa—good to see you again. Since this is our third call, I wanted to use the time to confirm what “good” looks like for Jetstream Vale Aviation and see if we can finalize next steps toward moving ahead with Sales_Accelerator.
Teresa Flores: Hi Megan. Yes, I’m here. I have about thirty minutes, but I’ll be honest—internally we still have some concerns we need to clear.

Megan Foster: Totally fair. Before we get into concerns, can I quickly recap what you said mattered most? You wanted tighter forecast accuracy, fewer end-of-quarter surprises, and more consistency in follow-up after discovery—especially for AEs who are juggling a lot of deals. Still accurate?
Teresa Flores: Yes. Our leadership is pushing hard on forecast accuracy. And our AEs are inconsistent—some are great at recap emails and action plans, others just… don’t do it.

Megan Foster: That maps directly to two parts of Sales_Accelerator we’ve focused on: the forecasting layer and the post-discovery follow-up recommendations. On forecasting, we’re not just reading CRM stage—Sales_Accelerator combines stage with activity signals like last touch, meeting scheduled or not, stage age, and your cycle-time benchmarks. Then it produces commit/best-case/pipeline views with explainable drivers, so when a deal slips, the “why” is visible.
Teresa Flores: The explainable part is important. We’ve had tools that spit out a number and nobody trusts it.

Megan Foster: Exactly. In our forecast view, if a deal drops from commit to best-case, it will tell you what changed—like “no next meeting scheduled,” “stage age above benchmark,” or “fit tier lower than typical wins,” if you choose to include the fit score input. That’s what drives adoption with managers: it’s not magic, it’s drivers you can audit.
Teresa Flores: Okay. And the AE follow-up side—how does that work in practice?

Megan Foster: After discovery, the AE clicks “Generate Follow-Up” on the opportunity. The tool drafts a recap email, pulls two proof points from your approved positioning library, and creates a mutual action plan with due dates and stakeholders—so you can multi-thread and keep momentum. The big value is consistency: even newer AEs get a solid baseline, and managers can see whether next steps are actually defined.

Teresa Flores: That’s appealing, but it’s also where our biggest concern is: privacy and compliance. Drafting emails from call notes, parsing meetings—there’s PII. We have aviation customers and sensitive data. Our legal team is very strict.

Megan Foster: Understood. Let me address it directly. Sales_Accelerator can be configured to limit what it ingests and how it retains it. We can also disable certain inputs—like not parsing raw emails or not storing call transcripts—while still getting value from CRM fields and activity metadata like “meeting happened” or “next meeting scheduled.” The follow-up drafting can be constrained to use only structured fields and your approved blocks.

Teresa Flores: When you say “configured,” that usually means “maybe.” Legal will ask for specifics: what data is processed, what’s stored, where, for how long, and whether it’s used for training anything.

Megan Foster: Fair. We don’t need to hand-wave it. I can share our data handling overview and we can align on a retention policy. Also, we can turn off model training on your data—so your content isn’t used to improve anything outside your tenant. But I’m guessing legal is also asking about consent and whether employees know their notes are being analyzed?
Teresa Flores: Yes. And we have union-related sensitivities around monitoring. Even if it’s “sales productivity,” it can be perceived as surveillance.

Megan Foster: That’s important context. In deployments like yours, we position it as deal-risk and execution support—not rep surveillance—and we can restrict dashboards so the focus is opportunity health rather than rep-level “activity scoring.” For example: managers can see “deals at risk due to no next step” rather than “Teresa made X calls.”
Teresa Flores: That helps, but again, our compliance team will want assurances that we aren’t extracting personal content from emails and storing it. They don’t like “drafting based on emails.”

Megan Foster: If drafting off emails is the sticking point, we can start with a narrower rollout: use the forecasting and deal-risk signals based on CRM plus meeting cadence, and keep follow-up drafting limited to manual inputs—like the AE selects which approved proof points to include, and the tool only formats the recap and action plan without reading raw notes.
Teresa Flores: So, essentially reduce the “AI reading everything” aspect.
Megan Foster: Exactly—phase it. You still get improved forecasting and early warnings on slippage. Then, once legal is comfortable, you expand to richer drafting.
Teresa Flores: The problem is leadership wants the follow-up standardization now. But legal is telling me we can’t proceed unless we have a full review, and that review could take months.

Megan Foster: Got it. If the timeline is the issue, could we run a pilot in a sandbox with synthetic data, just to prove workflow and value while legal reviews? That way you’re not blocked on momentum.
Teresa Flores: We considered that. But our ops team is swamped, and frankly we’ve done “pilots that go nowhere.” I’m trying to avoid another time sink.

Megan Foster: I hear you. Let me try a different angle: if we can’t use unstructured content initially, the strongest immediate ROI is forecasting accuracy and slippage diagnostics. That directly supports what leadership is pushing for. Would it still be valuable enough to justify moving forward while legal reviews the follow-up module?
Teresa Flores: Possibly. But leadership also asked: “Why buy a layer on top of Salesforce when we can tighten our process?” They want a clear justification.

Megan Foster: The justification is that process changes alone don’t give you explainable forecasting drivers across the whole pipeline. Salesforce stages don’t capture reality—activity, cycle time, and “next step exists” signals. Sales_Accelerator gives you a consistent system: commit/best-case/pipeline, plus scenario planning—like, “If we add 20 SQLs in Tier 1, what’s the expected impact?” That’s hard to do reliably with dashboards and spreadsheets.
Teresa Flores: Okay, but we’re also integrating Customer_Analyzer already. My VP asked if this duplicates work.

Megan Foster: It shouldn’t duplicate. Sales_Accelerator consumes Customer_Analyzer’s fit scores and positioning blocks. So you keep your ICP and messaging foundation in Customer_Analyzer; Sales_Accelerator uses that to weight forecasts and recommend next actions. It’s execution, not a second ICP tool.
Teresa Flores: Understood. Still, the privacy issue is non-negotiable. And I don’t have a path to get legal comfortable quickly.

Megan Foster: If legal needs a full review before any contract, that’s a hard gate. What would they need to see first—DPA, SOC 2, specifics on retention, and explicit statements that you can disable unstructured ingestion?

Teresa Flores: Yes, plus a security questionnaire, plus an internal risk committee review. And they’ll ask whether any employee communications are analyzed. Even if it’s optional, they don’t like the capability existing.
Megan Foster: That last point—“capability existing”—is tricky. Even if disabled, some orgs still view it as risk.
Teresa Flores: Exactly. That’s where we’re landing. Our compliance stance is conservative. We may be able to revisit later, but right now it’s not looking good.

Megan Foster: I appreciate you being direct. To make sure I’m not missing a workable route: if we offered a version that only uses CRM structured fields and activity metadata—no email bodies, no call transcripts, no note parsing—would that change the decision?

Teresa Flores: Maybe in theory, but I don’t think your product is positioned that way in our procurement. It would still trigger the same reviews, and we’d still be buying something leadership associates with “AI analyzing communications.” The perception is already set.

Megan Foster: Understood. Given that, it sounds like pushing for a close today isn’t realistic. Would it be helpful if I send a short summary you can forward internally—what we can and cannot ingest, and the phased approach—so you have clean documentation?
Teresa Flores: Yes, send that. But I want to set expectations: I don’t think we’ll be purchasing this quarter.
Megan Foster: That’s clear. Do you want to pause the evaluation entirely, or should we plan a check-in after legal has weighed in—say, in 8–12 weeks?
Teresa Flores: Let’s pause. If something changes, I’ll reach out. If you send the documentation, I can keep it on file.

Megan Foster: Okay. I’ll send the data handling overview, options to disable unstructured content processing, and a one-page outline of the forecasting value and slippage diagnostics—so if leadership revisits, you have the rationale. Anything else you need from me?
Teresa Flores: No, that’s enough. Thanks for being straightforward about it.
Megan Foster: Of course. Thanks for the time, Teresa. I’ll follow up by end of day with the docs, and we’ll leave it there unless you want to re-engage later.
Teresa Flores: Sounds good. Bye, Megan.
Megan Foster: Bye.
